evidence_items.text: A tug driving instructor (tug instructor) and trainee tug driver (trainee driver) were seated beside each other in the tug. The flight crew were in communication with the headset operator via the aircraft’s interphone.
The trainee driver decided to stop the pushback and asked the tug instructor to take over.

After swapping seats the instructor recommenced the pushback, correcting the aircraft back onto the taxiway centreline. He continued to reassure and advise the trainee while performing the pushback, looking at her while doing so. The headset operator continued walking on the right side of the tug, abeam its cabin. The wingman was on the left just ahead of the tug.

The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.
The tug instructor pulled the aircraft forward off the fence then stopped the tug.

The airport operator and ATC were notified. Soon after, representatives from the airport operator and the RFFS were on scene. The aircraft sustained substantial damage to the rear of the aircraft, including the APU, which was running at the time.
The TRP on Taxiway Delta is between Stands 61L and 61R. There is a 14.97 m clearance behind a B737-800 and the blast fence when its nosewheel is on the TRP.

The tug instructor stated that the method for getting a tug driver to stop quickly was to raise a clenched first, indicating the driver should apply the tug’s brakes. However, he suggested such a visual signal was not sufficient given a driver would be concentrating on the pushback, with the headset operator often out of his field of view. He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.

Trainee tug driver The trainee driver was qualified as a headset operator and wingman, and was aware of the TRP through the training for these roles. This was her second pushback. The first was completed earlier that day, without event.

The trainee driver reported that she felt the tug slow down as the aircraft’s nose wheel approached the TRP, so believed the instructor would stop the pushback. However, she did not say anything when he drove past the TRP, assuming he must have known what he was doing. After the collision, she suggested not moving the aircraft off the blast fence.
Headset operator The headset operator was also qualified as a wingman. Prior to this accident, he knew about TRPs from his training for the headset operator role but had not physically seen one.

He commented that the tug instructor took over when the aircraft was abeam Stand 62 and thereafter was attending to talking to the trainee. The tug slowed down when the aircraft was abeam Stand 61, so he positioned himself to disconnect the tug from the aircraft when it stopped. However, the aircraft continued to move slowly until it hit the blast fence. He said he assumed the instructor had a reason for that and did not question his actions.

Wingman The wingman was also a qualified headset operator. On the day of the accident, he had been called into work at short notice. To avoid delaying the pushback, he had not collected the marshalling wands from the tug. Nevertheless, it was not mandatory to use them. He commented that the TRP was quite small.

roots_spec.exclusion_clause: Not explained by any other root
Not explained by any other root
Not explained by any other root
Not explained by any other root

slot_statements.availability: The communication/coordination breakdown among crew was observed and documented in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA incident on 12-25 during the hist_t3_prefinal phase.
slot_statements.defeater_resistance: The communication/coordination breakdown among crew is supported by multiple sources and evidence from the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 hist_t3_prefinal data, making alternative explanations less plausible.
slot_statements.fit_to_key_features: The communication/coordination breakdown among crew aligns with key features of human factors contributing to aviation incidents, including miscommunication, lack of coordination, and failure to follow protocols.

node.statement: The communication/coordination breakdown among crew was observed and documented in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA incident on 12-25 during the hist_t3_prefinal phase.

assumptions: The lack of warnings and assumptions by crew members indicate communication breakdown
The incident context and crew roles as described are accurate and complete
defeaters: If evidence showed clear, effective communication and coordination among crew preventing the incident
If mechanical or environmental factors were primary causes rather than crew communication

quotes.exact_quote: He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.
She did not say anything when he drove past the TRP, assuming he must have known what he was doing.
He said he assumed the instructor had a reason for that and did not question his actions.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H8, H10, and H12 document lack of communication and coordination among crew during the pushback, supporting the claim of communication/coordination breakdown.
outcome.uncertainty_source: ambiguity in whether procedural deviation or communication breakdown was primary cause

slot_statements.availability: Mechanical/control failure was present in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA during the hist_t3_prefinal phase on 12-25.
slot_statements.defeater_resistance: The mechanical/control failure in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA during the hist_t3_prefinal phase is resistant to defeaters based on available evidence.
slot_statements.fit_to_key_features: The mechanical/control failure aligns with the key features observed in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA during the hist_t3_prefinal phase.

node.statement: Mechanical/control failure was present in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA during the hist_t3_prefinal phase on 12-25.

assumptions: No mechanical fault codes or bench checks were reported in the evidence
Descriptions of events accurately reflect the absence of mechanical/control failure
defeaters: If verified fault codes or repeat malfunctions indicating mechanical/control failure were found
If physical evidence of control malfunction was documented
If communication and procedural adherence were confirmed adequate

quotes.exact_quote: The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.

The tug instructor stated that the method for getting a tug driver to stop quickly was to raise a clenched first, indicating the driver should apply the tug’s brakes. However, he suggested such a visual signal was not sufficient given a driver would be concentrating on the pushback, with the headset operator often out of his field of view. He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.

The trainee driver reported that she felt the tug slow down as the aircraft’s nose wheel approached the TRP, so believed the instructor would stop the pushback. However, she did not say anything when he drove past the TRP, assuming he must have known what he was doing.

He commented that the tug instructor took over when the aircraft was abeam Stand 62 and thereafter was attending to talking to the trainee. The tug slowed down when the aircraft was abeam Stand 61, so he positioned himself to disconnect the tug from the aircraft when it stopped. However, the aircraft continued to move slowly until it hit the blast fence. He said he assumed the instructor had a reason for that and did not question his actions.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence (H1-H4, H8, H10, H12) shows the pushback continued past the TRP and hit the blast fence with no indication of mechanical/control failure; procedural deviations and communication issues are documented, supporting procedural or communication causes over mechanical failure.
outcome.uncertainty_source: absence of direct mechanical fault evidence and reliance on procedural and communication observations

slot_statements.availability: The environmental or marking deficiency must be present and identifiable in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA during the hist_t3_prefinal inspection on 12-25.
slot_statements.defeater_resistance: The identification of the environmental or marking deficiency must be robust against potential defeaters or exceptions in the context of the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA hist_t3_prefinal inspection on 12-25.
slot_statements.fit_to_key_features: The environmental or marking deficiency should correspond to the key features and criteria defined for the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA in the hist_t3_prefinal inspection on 12-25.

node.statement: The environmental or marking deficiency must be present and identifiable in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA during the hist_t3_prefinal inspection on 12-25.

assumptions: The TRP marking was present as described in H7 on the day of the incident.
The small size and visibility concerns noted in H13 and H8 relate to marking adequacy but do not prove absence.
defeaters: If evidence showed the TRP marking was missing or not visible on 12-25 during the hist_t3_prefinal inspection, or if multiple crew members reported inability to identify the marking.

quotes.exact_quote: The TRP on Taxiway Delta is between Stands 61L and 61R. There is a 14.97 m clearance behind a B737-800 and the blast fence when its nosewheel is on the TRP.

The tug instructor stated that the method for getting a tug driver to stop quickly was to raise a clenched first, indicating the driver should apply the tugs brakes. However, he suggested such a visual signal was not sufficient given a driver would be concentrating on the pushback, with the headset operator often out of his field of view. He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.
He commented that the TRP was quite small.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H7 confirms the TRP marking exists and is identifiable; however, H8 and H13 indicate issues with marker adequacy and visibility, favoring procedural deviation over environmental deficiency.
outcome.uncertainty_source: ambiguity in marker adequacy and visibility; no direct statement that marking was deficient or missing

slot_statements.availability: The procedural deviation in pushback execution is documented and observable within the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA during the 12-25 hist_t3 prefinal phase.
slot_statements.defeater_resistance: The procedural deviation in pushback execution withstands scrutiny against potential counterarguments or alternative explanations within the context of the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 hist_t3 prefinal.
slot_statements.fit_to_key_features: The procedural deviation in pushback execution aligns with key features identified for the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 hist_t3 prefinal, including timing, operator actions, and environmental conditions.

node.statement: The procedural deviation in pushback execution is documented and observable within the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA during the 12-25 hist_t3 prefinal phase.

assumptions: The TRP ground markings are considered adequate and visible as per H7 and H13
No mechanical control failure occurred as no evidence supports it
defeaters: If evidence showed mechanical failure or environmental marking deficiencies caused the event rather than operator procedural deviation
If communication breakdown was proven to be the primary cause rather than procedural deviation

quotes.exact_quote: The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.
The trainee driver decided to stop the pushback and asked the tug instructor to take over.

The tug instructor stated that the method for getting a tug driver to stop quickly was to raise a clenched first, indicating the driver should apply the tug’s brakes. However, he suggested such a visual signal was not sufficient given a driver would be concentrating on the pushback, with the headset operator often out of his field of view. He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H4 documents the procedural deviation with the aircraft passing the TRP and hitting the blast barrier. H2 and H8 show the pushback was controlled by the tug instructor who took over and failed to stop at the TRP despite signals and awareness, supporting the claim of documented procedural deviation in the specified aircraft and phase.
outcome.uncertainty_source: Some ambiguity in communication and signaling effectiveness, but overall evidence favors procedural deviation

node.statement: The communication/coordination breakdown among crew aligns with key features of human factors contributing to aviation incidents, including miscommunication, lack of coordination, and failure to follow protocols.

assumptions: The crew roles and their communication responsibilities are as described in the evidence.
No other unreported factors significantly influenced the incident.
defeaters: If evidence showed clear, effective communication and adherence to protocols by all crew members.
If environmental or marking deficiencies were proven to be the primary cause rather than crew communication failures.

quotes.exact_quote: He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.
She did not say anything when he drove past the TRP, assuming he must have known what he was doing.
He said he assumed the instructor had a reason for that and did not question his actions.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H8, H10, and H12 show miscommunication and lack of coordination among crew members, including failure to warn or question actions, supporting the claim of communication/coordination breakdown as a key human factor.
outcome.uncertainty_source: Some ambiguity exists about the adequacy of visual signals and the role of environmental factors, but evidence favors communication breakdown.

node.statement: The communication/coordination breakdown among crew is supported by multiple sources and evidence from the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 hist_t3_prefinal data, making alternative explanations less plausible.

defeaters: If evidence showed clear, effective communication and coordination among crew or if marking deficiencies were proven to be the primary cause, this would change the assessment.

node.statement: The environmental or marking deficiency should correspond to the key features and criteria defined for the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA in the hist_t3_prefinal inspection on 12-25.

assumptions: The TRP marking described applies specifically to the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA context on 12-25.
The statements about marking visibility and adequacy reflect the actual conditions during the incident.
defeaters: If additional evidence showed the TRP markings were fully adequate and clearly visible to all crew members, or if procedural deviations were the sole cause of the incident, this would change the assessment.

quotes.exact_quote: The TRP on Taxiway Delta is between Stands 61L and 61R. There is a 14.97 m clearance behind a B737-800 and the blast fence when its nosewheel is on the TRP.

The tug instructor stated that the method for getting a tug driver to stop quickly was to raise a clenched first, indicating the driver should apply the tugs brakes. However, he suggested such a visual signal was not sufficient given a driver would be concentrating on the pushback, with the headset operator often out of his field of view. He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.
He commented that the TRP was quite small.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H7, H8, and H13 directly describe the TRP marking characteristics and visibility issues, supporting that the environmental or marking deficiency fits the key features for the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA prefinal inspection.
outcome.uncertainty_source: ambiguity in whether the marking visibility alone caused the event or if procedural factors predominated

defeaters: Direct evidence of hardware faults or control malfunctions during the pushback phase.
Bench checks or fault codes confirming mechanical/control failure.

node.statement: The procedural deviation in pushback execution aligns with key features identified for the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 hist_t3 prefinal, including timing, operator actions, and environmental conditions.

assumptions: The described operator actions and environmental conditions constitute the key features for procedural deviation.
No significant communication breakdown occurred that would better explain the event.
defeaters: If evidence showed the headset operator or wingman had effectively communicated warnings that were ignored, or if the instructor's actions were due to miscommunication rather than procedural deviation.

children_spec.statement: Crew members were physically present and reachable during the operation
children_spec.test_procedure: Check crew attendance logs, communication device records, and physical presence reports to confirm availability

children_spec.statement: Communication devices and channels were operational and accessible to all crew members
children_spec.test_procedure: Verify maintenance and functionality reports of radios, intercoms, and other communication equipment used by the crew

children_spec.statement: Crew members were not engaged in conflicting tasks that prevented timely communication
children_spec.test_procedure: Review task logs and crew activity timelines to identify any overlapping duties that could hinder communication availability

node.statement: Crew members were physically present and reachable during the operation

defeaters: If evidence showed crew members were physically separated or unreachable during the operation
If communication devices were non-functional or crew were incapacitated

outcome.uncertainty_source: None significant; evidence directly supports physical presence and reachability

node.statement: Communication devices and channels were operational and accessible to all crew members

defeaters: If evidence showed that warnings or alerts were effectively communicated and acknowledged by all crew members before the incident.

quotes.exact_quote: The flight crew were in communication with the headset operator via the aircraft’s interphone.
He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.
He said he assumed the instructor had a reason for that and did not question his actions.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H1 confirms communication devices were operational; however, H8 and H12 indicate no warnings or alerts were given despite the impending collision, contradicting the claim that communication devices and channels were accessible and effectively used by all crew members.
outcome.uncertainty_source: ambiguity in whether communication devices were accessible but not effectively used or if there were other barriers to communication.

node.statement: The procedural deviation in pushback execution withstands scrutiny against potential counterarguments or alternative explanations within the context of the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 hist_t3 prefinal.

assumptions: Crew statements accurately reflect their perceptions and actions
No undisclosed environmental or mechanical issues influenced the pushback
defeaters: If new evidence showed explicit communication breakdown or miscoordination among crew members causing the deviation
If environmental or mechanical factors were proven to have forced the deviation

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H1-H3, H8, H10, and H12 show the procedural deviation was deliberate and not due to communication failure, supporting the claim that the deviation withstands counterarguments related to coordination failure.

children_spec.statement: The pushback procedure deviated from the standard checklist steps
children_spec.test_procedure: Review the recorded checklist steps during pushback and compare them to the standard procedure to identify any omissions or additions

children_spec.statement: The timing and sequencing of pushback actions did not conform to prescribed protocols
children_spec.test_procedure: Analyze the timing logs and video recordings of pushback to verify if actions occurred in the correct order and within expected timeframes

children_spec.statement: Communication between ground crew and flight crew during pushback was inconsistent with procedural standards
children_spec.test_procedure: Examine radio transcripts and audio recordings for adherence to communication protocols during pushback

children_spec.statement: Use of pushback equipment did not follow manufacturer or airline operational guidelines
children_spec.test_procedure: Inspect equipment usage logs and maintenance records to confirm compliance with operational guidelines during pushback

node.statement: Crew members were not engaged in conflicting tasks that prevented timely communication

defeaters: If evidence showed explicit, timely communication warnings or alerts among crew members preventing the incident.
If crew members were not engaged in other tasks or distractions during the pushback.

quotes.exact_quote: He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.
She did not say anything when he drove past the TRP, assuming he must have known what he was doing.
He said he assumed the instructor had a reason for that and did not question his actions.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence (H8, H10, H12) shows crew members were engaged in tasks and assumptions that prevented timely communication, contradicting the claim that no conflicting tasks prevented communication.
outcome.uncertainty_source: ambiguity in crew communication dynamics and assumptions made during the event

node.statement: Communication between ground crew and flight crew during pushback was inconsistent with procedural standards

assumptions: Procedural standards require consistent and effective communication between ground and flight crews during pushback.
Lack of warnings or questioning by crew members indicates communication inconsistency.
defeaters: If evidence showed clear, timely, and effective communication between ground and flight crews during pushback.
If the procedural standards allowed for the communication patterns observed.

quotes.exact_quote: He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.
She did not say anything when he drove past the TRP, assuming he must have known what he was doing.
He said he assumed the instructor had a reason for that and did not question his actions.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H8, H10, and H12 indicate communication between ground crew and flight crew was insufficient or ineffective, supporting the claim of inconsistent communication with procedural standards.
outcome.uncertainty_source: ambiguity in communication effectiveness and lack of explicit procedural communication standards in evidence.

node.statement: The pushback procedure deviated from the standard checklist steps

assumptions: Standard pushback procedure requires stopping at the TRP.
Continuing beyond the TRP without stopping constitutes procedural deviation.
defeaters: If evidence showed that the TRP markings were inadequate or not visible, or if equipment malfunction caused the pushback to continue, this would change the conclusion.

quotes.exact_quote: The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.

The tug instructor stated that the method for getting a tug driver to stop quickly was to raise a clenched first, indicating the driver should apply the tug’s brakes. However, the aircraft continued to move slowly until it hit the blast fence. He said he assumed the instructor had a reason for that and did not question his actions.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H4, H8, and H12 directly describe the pushback continuing beyond the TRP and the tug instructor's actions, indicating deviation from standard checklist steps rather than environmental or marking deficiencies.
outcome.uncertainty_source: No direct checklist steps are quoted; assumptions about standard procedure are made based on typical TRP stopping behavior.

node.statement: The timing and sequencing of pushback actions did not conform to prescribed protocols

assumptions: The TRP ground markings and their visibility were adequate as per H7 and H13.
No mechanical faults were reported or indicated in evidence.
defeaters: If evidence showed mechanical control failure or environmental marking inadequacy caused the pushback beyond TRP, or if communication breakdown was primary cause, this would change the conclusion.

He commented that the tug instructor took over when the aircraft was abeam Stand 62 and thereafter was attending to talking to the trainee. The tug slowed down when the aircraft was abeam Stand 61, so he positioned himself to disconnect the tug from the aircraft when it stopped. However, the aircraft continued to move slowly until it hit the blast fence. He said he assumed the instructor had a reason for that and did not question his actions.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H4, H8, H10, and H12 directly describe the pushback continuing beyond the TRP contrary to protocol, with no mechanical failure or environmental marking issues preventing compliance, supporting procedural deviation.
outcome.uncertainty_source: Some ambiguity in communication and signaling effectiveness, but direct evidence supports procedural deviation.

node.statement: The identification of the environmental or marking deficiency must be robust against potential defeaters or exceptions in the context of the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA hist_t3_prefinal inspection on 12-25.

defeaters: If evidence showed clear, unambiguous, and visible environmental or marking deficiencies that were recognized and acted upon by the crew, this would support the claim.
If communication and coordination among crew and support personnel were confirmed to be effective and not contributing factors.

quotes.exact_quote: He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.
He said he assumed the instructor had a reason for that and did not question his actions.
To avoid delaying the pushback, he had not collected the marshalling wands from the tug. Nevertheless, it was not mandatory to use them. He commented that the TRP was quite small.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H8, H12, and H13 indicate communication and coordination issues rather than environmental or marking deficiencies, contradicting the claim that the identification of environmental or marking deficiency was robust against defeaters.
outcome.uncertainty_source: ambiguity in whether marking visibility or communication failures were primary contributors

node.statement: Use of pushback equipment did not follow manufacturer or airline operational guidelines

assumptions: The TRP markings and environment were adequate and visible as per H7 and H13
No mechanical faults occurred as no evidence indicates such
Operator actions and decisions reflect procedural adherence or deviation
defeaters: If evidence showed mechanical failure or control malfunction causing the pushback to continue beyond TRP
If environmental markings were inadequate or not visible, explaining the deviation
If communication breakdown was proven to have caused the failure to stop

quotes.exact_quote: The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.

The tug instructor stated that the method for getting a tug driver to stop quickly was to raise a clenched first, indicating the driver should apply the tug’s brakes. However, he suggested such a visual signal was not sufficient given a driver would be concentrating on the pushback, with the headset operator often out of his field of view. He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.

The trainee driver reported that she felt the tug slow down as the aircraft’s nose wheel approached the TRP, so believed the instructor would stop the pushback. However, she did not say anything when he drove past the TRP, assuming he must have known what he was doing.

He commented that the tug instructor took over when the aircraft was abeam Stand 62 and thereafter was attending to talking to the trainee. The tug slowed down when the aircraft was abeam Stand 61, so he positioned himself to disconnect the tug from the aircraft when it stopped. However, the aircraft continued to move slowly until it hit the blast fence. He said he assumed the instructor had a reason for that and did not question his actions.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H4, H8, H10, and H12 directly describe the pushback continuing beyond the TRP contrary to expected stopping behavior, with no warnings or mechanical faults reported, supporting procedural deviation rather than communication failure or environmental/technical causes.
outcome.uncertainty_source: No direct evidence of mechanical failure or environmental marking deficiency; reliance on operator statements and observations

children_spec.statement: Required environmental markings are physically present at the location
children_spec.test_procedure: Inspect the location to verify the presence of all required environmental markings

children_spec.statement: Environmental markings are visible under current lighting and weather conditions
children_spec.test_procedure: Assess visibility of markings during the relevant lighting and weather conditions

children_spec.statement: Environmental markings are maintained and not obscured or damaged
children_spec.test_procedure: Examine markings for wear, damage, or obstructions that reduce availability

node.statement: The mechanical/control failure in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA during the hist_t3_prefinal phase is resistant to defeaters based on available evidence.

assumptions: No direct hardware fault codes or bench checks indicating mechanical failure were reported.
Visual signals and communication attempts were insufficient to prevent the incident, supporting mechanical/control failure over procedural or communication causes.
defeaters: If evidence showed verified hardware faults or repeat malfunctions directly causing the pushback beyond TRP, or if procedural deviations were clearly documented and causative, the defeater resistance claim would weaken.
If communication failures were proven to have prevented any corrective action, undermining mechanical failure as the cause.

quotes.exact_quote: The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.

The tug instructor stated that the method for getting a tug driver to stop quickly was to raise a clenched first, indicating the driver should apply the tug’s brakes. However, he suggested such a visual signal was not sufficient given a driver would be concentrating on the pushback, with the headset operator often out of his field of view. He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.

The trainee driver reported that she felt the tug slow down as the aircraft’s nose wheel approached the TRP, so believed the instructor would stop the pushback. However, she did not say anything when he drove past the TRP, assuming he must have known what he was doing.
He said he assumed the instructor had a reason for that and did not question his actions.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence (H4, H8, H10, H12) shows the aircraft moved past the TRP despite visual signals and communication attempts, indicating the mechanical/control failure explanation is robust against defeaters related to procedural deviation or communication breakdown. Environmental deficiency is contradicted by clear TRP markings (H7) and no physical marking issues.
outcome.uncertainty_source: Some ambiguity in communication effectiveness and procedural adherence; no direct hardware fault codes presented.

children_spec.statement: Crew members were physically present and accessible during the event
children_spec.test_procedure: Check crew attendance logs, cockpit voice recordings, and witness statements to confirm presence and accessibility

children_spec.statement: Communication devices and channels among crew were operational and available
children_spec.test_procedure: Review maintenance records and system logs for communication equipment functionality and availability during the event

children_spec.statement: Crew members attempted to communicate or coordinate during the event
children_spec.test_procedure: Analyze cockpit voice recorder and other communication records for evidence of communication attempts

children_spec.statement: No external factors prevented communication or coordination among crew
children_spec.test_procedure: Investigate environmental and situational factors such as noise, stress, or interference that could have impeded communication

children_spec.statement: Mechanical components required for control are physically present and intact
children_spec.test_procedure: Inspect the aircraft's mechanical control components for presence and physical integrity; absence or damage would lower probability

children_spec.statement: Mechanical control components are free from obstructions or blockages
children_spec.test_procedure: Check for any foreign objects, debris, or mechanical jams in control linkages; detection of obstructions would lower probability

children_spec.statement: Mechanical control components are properly connected and aligned
children_spec.test_procedure: Verify mechanical linkages and connections for proper alignment and secure attachment; misalignment or disconnection would lower probability

children_spec.statement: Mechanical control components are not degraded or worn beyond operational limits
children_spec.test_procedure: Assess wear and degradation levels of mechanical parts against maintenance standards; excessive wear would lower probability

node.statement: Communication devices and channels among crew were operational and available

defeaters: If evidence showed communication devices were malfunctioning or unavailable
If crew reported inability to communicate during the incident

quotes.exact_quote: The flight crew were in communication with the headset operator via the aircraft’s interphone.
Headset operator was also qualified as a wingman. Prior to this accident, he knew about TRPs from his training for the headset operator role but had not physically seen one.

He commented that the tug instructor took over when the aircraft was abeam Stand 62 and thereafter was attending to talking to the trainee. The tug slowed down when the aircraft was abeam Stand 61, so he positioned himself to disconnect the tug from the aircraft when it stopped. However, the aircraft continued to move slowly until it hit the blast fence. He said he assumed the instructor had a reason for that and did not question his actions.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H1, H11, and H12 indicate communication devices and channels among crew were operational and available, contradicting the claim of communication breakdown.
outcome.uncertainty_source: none

node.statement: Crew members attempted to communicate or coordinate during the event

defeaters: If evidence showed no communication attempts or explicit communication failures, or if mechanical failure was the sole cause without coordination issues.

quotes.exact_quote: The flight crew were in communication with the headset operator via the aircraft’s interphone.
The trainee driver decided to stop the pushback and asked the tug instructor to take over.

After swapping seats the instructor recommenced the pushback, correcting the aircraft back onto the taxiway centreline. He continued to reassure and advise the trainee while performing the pushback, looking at her while doing so.
He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.

The trainee driver reported that she felt the tug slow down as the aircraft’s nose wheel approached the TRP, so believed the instructor would stop the pushback. However, she did not say anything when he drove past the TRP, assuming he must have known what he was doing.
He said he assumed the instructor had a reason for that and did not question his actions.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H1, H2, H3, H8, H10, and H12 directly describe communication and coordination attempts among crew members during the event, supporting the claim that crew members attempted to communicate or coordinate.
outcome.uncertainty_source: None significant; evidence is direct and consistent.
